questions.text: The newborn eye is usually ______.
questions.solution:
A newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2D to +3D.  

The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the eyeball at birth is about 16.5 mm, which is about 70% of the adult size. This reduced axial length causes light to converge behind the retina, leading to hypermetropia. 

Additionally, the corneal diameter at birth is 10 mm. The adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age. The orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adult (45°).

Note: The lacrimal glands are underdeveloped in a newborn and, hence, do not secrete tears.

questions.text: At what age would a child attain full visual acuity?
questions.solution:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years.

Important milestones in visual development are:

  • At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly.
  • By the first month of life, the fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months.
  • By 3 months, binocular vision is established.
  • By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed.
  • By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

Related Pearl: Summary of ocular embryogenesis

Period after conception
Major milestone
3 weeks
  • Optic groove appears
4th week
  • Optic pit develops into an optic vesicle
  • Lens plate forms
  • Embryonic fissure develops 
1st month
  • Lens pit develops, followed by formation of the lens vesicle
  • Hyaloid vessels develop
1.5 months
  • Closure of the embryonic fissure
  • Differentiation of retinal pigment epithelium
  • Appearance of eyelid folds and nasolacrimal duct
7th week
  • Embryonic nucleus of the lens
  • Sclera begins to form
  • Migration of waves of the neural crest
  • 1st wave: corneal and trabecular endothelium
  • 2nd wave: corneal stroma
  • 3rd wave: iris stroma
3rd  month
  • Differentiation of precursors of rods and cone
  • Anterior chamber appears
  • Fetal nucleus starts to develop
  • Sclera condenses 
4th month
  • Formation of retinal vasculature begins
  • Hyaloid vessels regress
  • Formation of physiological optic disc cup and lamina cribrosa
  • Canal of Schlemm appears
  • Bowman's membrane develops
  • Formation of the major arterial circle and sphincter muscle of the iris
5th month
  • Photoreceptors differentiate
  • Eyelid separation begins
6th month
  • Differentiation of the dilator pupillae muscle
  • Nasolacrimal system becomes patent
  • Cones differentiate
7th month
  • Rods differentiate
  • Myelination of optic nerve begins
8th month
  • Completion of the anterior chamber angle
  • Hyaloid vessels disappear
9th month
  • Pupillary membrane disappears

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents with the abnormality as shown below. She is diagnosed with uveal melanoma. What is the embryological origin of the cells involved?
questions.solution:
Uveal melanomas arise from uveal melanocytes.  Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes are derived from the neural crest cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of the eye?

choices.text: The macula is fully developed at birth.
The cornea attains normal diameter by 2 years.
Full visual acuity is attained by 6 years of age.

questions.solution:
The macula is fully developed by 4–6 months of age. Apart from the macula, the rest of the retina is fully developed at birth.

Postnatal Development of Eye: 

  • 3 Months - Binocular single vision develops.
  • 4-6 Months - Macula fully develops. Fusional reflexes, stereopsis, and accommodation become well developed
  • 6 Months - Fixation, which had started developing in the first month is now complete
  • 2 Years - Cornea develops to the normal adult diameter
  • 6 Years - Visual acuity fully develops and reaches 6/6
  • The lens, however, continues to grow throughout the life

Related Pearl: Visual development

Age
Visual development
At birth
Fixation at light held 8–10 inches away - momentarily
6–8 weeks
Fixation at light and moving objects - more steadily
3 months
Follows moving objects
5–6 months
Depth perception, color vision, and eye–body coordination

questions.text: By how many weeks of embryonic development does the optic groove appear?
questions.solution:
The optic groove appears by 3 weeks. By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

questions.text: Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from _______.
questions.solution:
Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from the neural crest.

questions.text: After conception, the canal of Schlemm appears by __________________ .
questions.solution:
The canal of Schlemm appears by the 4th month after conception.

questions.text: What is the anteroposterior diameter of the adult eyeball?
questions.solution:
The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the adult eye is 24 mm/2.4 cm. 

At birth, the average axial length of the eyeball is 16.5 mm. By 3 years, it grows rapidly to approximately 23 mm. From 3 to 14 years of age, the axial length gradually increases by a further 1 mm, bringing it to the adult size of 24 mm. This overall adjustment in the eye size, including the refractive power, is called emmetropization.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady comes to the clinic complaining of problems in her vision. On perimetry, a visual field defect as shown below is obtained. Which of the following vessels does not supply the anatomical location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The image shows bitemporal hemianopia, a defect caused by optic chiasmal lesions. The middle cerebral artery does not supply the optic chiasma.

Blood supply of optic chiasma:

  • Anterior cerebral artery - dorsal chiasma
  • Anterior communicating artery - ventral chiasma
  • Internal carotid artery - ventral chiasma
  • Superior hypophyseal artery - ventral (branch of internal carotid artery).

questions.text: A college student comes to the OPD for refractive error testing. Her eyes are dilated using tropicamide. Which of the following statements is false about the structure this drug acts on?

choices.text: It is triangular in cross section.
There are around 30-40 processes in pars plana and pars plicata
Its epithelium is derived from the anterior edge of the optic cup.
The pars plana is approximately 4.5 mm from the limbus.

questions.solution:
Tropicamide is a cycloplegic drug that acts on the ciliary body to cause mydriasis for refractory error testing. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that contains 60-70 ciliary processes in each eye, present on the pars plicata.

The pars plana is 4.5mm from the limbus while the distance between the equator and the limbus is 14mm. 

The ciliary epithelium is derived from the optic cup (neuroectoderm) by the continued growth of the outer lip's anterior edge.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl you examined in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What is the most common site where the condition is seen?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant.

A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types: 

  • Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation.
  • Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary body and a part of choroid.

Other embryonic remnants in the eye: 

  • Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid artery
  • Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid artery
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress   

The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of decreased vision. Fundus examination shows a developmental anomaly as shown below. What is the cause of this anomaly?

choices.text: Incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure
Faulty migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
The image shows a coloboma of the optic disc, accompanied by a large chorioretinal coloboma located below the optic disc, which is caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.

This developmental anomaly may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. Coloboma of the optic disc can present in two forms: a minor effect often associated with refractive errors like hypermetropia and astigmatism and a fully developed coloboma that appears as a large inferonasal whitish excavation resembling the optic disc. 

Defective vision and superior visual field defects are typically associated with fully developed coloboma. Additionally, this condition may be associated with chorioretinal coloboma, a congenital anomaly where the developing optic cup fails to fuse completely, leading to abnormal choroidal and retinal development. 

Note: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The lacrimal gland arises from the surface ectoderm.

questions.text: The optic foramen is situated between the:

choices.text: Lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid
Lesser wing and body of the sphenoid
Greater wing and body of the sphenoid
Two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid

questions.solution:
The optic foramen is situated between the two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid. 

The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is formed medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa.

The optic canal transmits the optic nerve with its meningeal coverings; the ophthalmic artery, which is below the nerve, is embedded in its dural sheath, and a few twigs from the sympathetic plexus accompanying the artery.

questions.text: During a game, a 26-year-old baseball player is hit in the head by a baseball, which fractures the optic canal. Which of the following pairs of structures is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a fracture of the optic canal is most likely to damage the ophthalmic artery and optic nerve, as these are the primary structures passing through it.

The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is a short cylindrical structure bounded medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa, serving as a pathway for the aforementioned structures along with its sympathetic plexus. 

Optic canal fractures, often associated with basilar skull fractures, can lead to optic neuropathy. The intracanalicular and intracranial portion of the optic nerve is most commonly affected in head trauma. 

Note: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bound the superior orbital fissure. 

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: The anterior segment of the eye includes all except ______.
questions.solution:
The anterior segment of the eye does not include vitreous humor as it is a constituent of the posterior segment of the eye.

Anterior Segment Posterior Segment 
Cornea Vitreous humor 
Iris  Retina 
Lens  Choroid
Anterior and Posterior chambers with aqueous humor  Optic Disc

questions.text: The posterior chamber in the eyeball is filled with _______.
questions.solution:
The posterior chamber of the eyeball is filled with aqueous humor.

The eyeball is divided into anterior and posterior segments. The anterior segment includes the lens and the structures anterior to it, such as the cornea, iris and two aqueous humor-filled spaces:

  • Anterior chamber:  Located between cornea and iris, contains aqueous humor and communicates with the posterior chamber through the pupil. 
  • Posterior chamber: Triangular-shaped space, also contains aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly by the posterior surface of the iris, laterally by the ciliary body, and posteriorly by the lens. 

The posterior segment includes all structures located posterior to the lens, comprising of the vitreous humor, retina, choroid and optic disc.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle?

choices.text: Check ligament of the medial rectus
Check ligament of the lateral rectus

questions.solution:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle.

Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the fronto-zygomatic suture.

Four structures are attached to it:

  1. Check ligament of the lateral rectus
  2. Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball)
  3. Lateral palpebral ligament
  4. Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis

The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior tarsal plate and the orbital bone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tarsal plates?

choices.text: They give structural support to the eyelid.
LPS aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.
Their medial and lateral ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments, respectively.

questions.solution:
The tarsal plates are not cartilaginous structures but firm, dense connective tissue (fibrous tissue) plates.

The tarsal plates serve as the structural support of the eyelids. The height of the upper tarsal plate is about 10 mm, and that of the lower tarsal plate is 4 mm. Both plates have a thickness of about 1 mm. The ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments (medial and lateral canthal tendons). The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.

The meibomian glands are located within the tarsus. These are holocrine-secreting sebaceous glands that are not associated with lash follicles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is being evaluated for herpes zoster ophthalmicus. On eliciting corneal reflex, there is no response. Which of the following nerves forms the afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.solution:
The sensory supply of the cornea comes from the long ciliary nerve (branch of the nasociliary nerve). It forms the afferent limb of the corneal reflex. 

The sensory nerve supply of the eye is by the ophthalmic nerve.

  • Lacrimal nerve- lacrimal gland, conjunctiva, lateral eyelid
  • Frontal nerve- conjunctiva, eyelid, part of the forehead
  • Nasociliary nerve
    • Long ciliary nerve- cornea, ciliary body, iris
    • Infra-trochlear nerve- conjunctiva, lacrimal sac, caruncle, medial part of the eyelids

Corneal sensation is reduced in leprosy and diabetes mellitus (neuropathy).

questions.text: Which intrinsic ocular muscle has a parasympathetic innervation?
questions.solution:
The intrinsic ocular muscle supplied by parasympathetic innervation is the sphincter pupillae.

1. Parasympathetic innervation:

  • Sphincter pupillae: Short ciliary nerve–Ciliary ganglion
  • Ciliary muscle–Accessory ganglion 

2. Sympathetic innervation: Dilator pupillae and Muller’s muscle

3. Motor Supply:

  • 3rd nerve: All extraocular muscles (except the 2 given below)
  • 6th nerve: Lateral rectus (LR6)
  • 4th nerve: Superior oblique (SO4)
  • 7th nerve: Orbicularis oculi

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: What is the thinnest part of the retina?
questions.solution:
The retina is the thinnest (0.080 mm) at the ora serrata, and thickest, at the foveal rim (0.23, 0.320 mm).

The ora serrata is the serrated junction between the retina and ciliary body.

questions.text: In the anatomy dissection hall, you are shown the dissected orbit with the markers as shown below. You are asked to choose the muscles causing depression of the eyeball. Which will you choose?
questions.solution:
The muscles responsible for the depression of the eyeball are the inferior rectus (E) and superior oblique (A). 

Image markings: 

  • A- Superior oblique
  • B- Levator palpebrae superiors
  • C- Superior rectus
  • D- Inferior oblique
  • E- Inferior rectus

 

Nerve supply of extra-ocular muscles: 

  • Oculomotor nerve (III)- Superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, inferior oblique, and levator palpebrae superioris
  • Abducens nerve (VI)- Lateral rectus 
  • Trochlear nerve (IV)- Superior oblique

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions
